Did Play School build a bong? Play School host Alex Papps builds an interesting object in a old Play School episode that has raised eyebrows.
PT0M37S http://www.canberratimes.com.au/action/externalEmbeddedPlayer?id=d-443xh 620 349 October 9, 2015 - 8:13AM Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings It is the beloved children's television program that has often provided the odd giggle for parents and other grown-ups forced to watch it, thanks to the engagingly silly antics of its adult hosts and odd moment of gentle innuendo.
The ABC's Play School now has another such giggle-worthy moment thanks to a crafty device   constructed by its hosts . 
In an old craft segment that has gone viral on social media this week, host Alex Papps built an object out of a plastic bottle and straw which, as many pointed out, ended up resembling a home-made bong.
Host Alex Papps doing a craft project on Play School that many viewers on social media say looks like a homemade bong. Photo: Twitter 
The host poked a small hole in the side of the bottle, poked the straw through it and sealed it in place, and then filled the bottle with water - a fairly similar technique to that used by generations of Australian stoners, armed with juice or soft drink bottles and cut-off pieces of garden hose to make their own bongs (or so we've heard).
Advertisement Screenshots of the craft project - which of course had nothing to do with drug use and was a perfectly innocent piece of children's programming - have provided much amusement for users of social media and sites like Reddit, where one user declared: 'Ok. Time for an ABC Inquiry. They're making bongs on Play School.'
"In the ning nang nong where the cows smoke bongs," replied another.
Dear @ABCMediaWatch can you have a word to Play School? They're teaching my daughter to make a bong. pic.twitter.com/aWQ0Yd7M 
— sharktoppotomus (@sgordo13) November 4, 2012 Why is this Play School host making a bong? via @justipen pic.twitter.com/SluCGzBdiF 
— Osman Faruqi (@oz_f) October 8, 2015 Is that a bong on Play School? pic.twitter.com/7L0rbtkMh5 
— vegemiteblonde (@vegemiteblonde) March 11, 2015 It's not the first time the show has provided mirth for adults.
Former presenter Benita Collings remembered some of the funnier moments in a Fairfax article in 2012 . 

In one episode, Collings was pretending to be a house, while co-host John Hamblin was walking around her saying, 'This is a nice strong house,"' she said.
"He walked in front of me, talking about the windows and so on. Then he went behind me and said, 'Lovely rear entrance,' and kept going.

"He could do that. The adults would get it and fall about, the kids would just think, 'Oh yeah, lovely rear access."'
